Highlights
 New Alumina (Al2O3) and Carbon Black (CB) based nano-PCMs were
developed.
 Two pure paraffin waxes were used as reference PCMs.
 CB based nano-PCMs showed high thermal conductivity enhancement,
more than 25%.
 Al2O3 based nano-PCMs showed the highest latent heat improvement,
more than 10%.
Abstract It is well known that the heat transfer associated with a phase change process is much higher than sensible enthalpy change even in forced convection. In particular, the vaporization process has been widely studied because it exploits the highest heat transfer coefficient; this heat transfer mechanism is used in both passive (i.e. heat pipes) and active (i.e. refrigerating machines) cooling devices. However, the solidliquid phase change process is another interesting possibility to reject even high heat loads, especially when they are intermittent. The term Phase Change Materials (PCMs) commonly refers to those materials, which use the solid-liquid phase change process to adsorb and then release heat loads [1]. The present work aims at investigating the feasibility of a new challenging use of Aluminium Oxide (Al2O3) and Carbon Black (CB) nanoparticles to enhance the thermal properties: thermal conductivity, specific heat, and latent heat of pure paraffin waxes to obtain a new class of PCMs, the so-called nano-PCMs. The nano-PCMs were obtained by seeding 1%wt of nanoparticles in paraffin waxes with melting temperatures of 20 °C and 25 °C. The thermophysical properties were then measured to understand the effects of the nanoparticles on the thermal properties of both the solid and liquid PCM. These new nano-PCMs can represent a feasible and interesting way to mitigate or eliminate the intrinsic limitations in the use of paraffin waxes as PCMs for both energy storage and passive cooling applications.
Keywords: PCM, nanoparticle, energy storage, passive cooling, Al2O3, Carbon Black

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
The development of energy storage devices is crucial to the present day and represents an exciting opportunity for innovation. Water tank, for instance, can be considered the simplest energy storage, where rejecting heat, which can successively be released by the system. Therefore, an energy storage method must be reversible. The sensible energy storage can be improved by using a medium, which, at the typical operating temperature of the system, changes from solid to liquid (melting) during the loading period and viceversa (solidification) during the unloading operations. In other words, this new storage might use the latent heat of a suitable material to store more energy, keeping the storage temperature almost constant. Materials with this characteristic are called Phase Change Materials (PCMs), which are considered potential solutions for energy saving. PCM applications include several fields, e.g. solar plants, photovoltaic cells, solar collectors, thermal management systems, transportation, and storage of foods and medicine. In the last decade, the use of PCMs as heat storage in passive heat transfer device has been widely studied both analytically and experimentally. The use of the latent heat absorption phenomenon associated with melting of a suitable PCM can be considered an effective way to delay or modify the temperature rise of a surface subjected to high and intermittent heat fluxes. The intrinsic advantage of the PCM systems is related to their simplicity and reliability; however, the reversible phase change process must be carefully analysed in order to avoid any unmanageable situations during the real operation of these devices. As described in many comprehensive reviews [2-4] published in the open literature, PCMs have been widely proposed for thermal storage applications due to their capability of storing and releasing large amounts of energy with a small PCM volume and a relatively low temperature variation. As described by Sharma et al. [3], a large number of phase change materials (organic, inorganic, and eutectic) are available in any required temperature range. An ideal PCM should exhibit a suitable phase-transition temperature, high latent heat of fusion, and high thermal conductivity; it should be characterized by high density associated with a small volume change during the melting process and low vapour pressure in the melt; moreover, it should be chemically stable over a long period of time, nontoxic and non-hazardous, and compatible with the building materials. Finally, it should be abundant, available, and cost effective.
Page 3 of 18
Amongst the available PCMs, paraffin waxes have been found to exhibit many desirable characteristics, such as high latent heat, low vapour pressure in the melt, chemical inertia and stability, non-toxicity. However, they also have a very low thermal conductivity and a high volume change during the melting process. Thus, heat transfer enhancement techniques are required for their possible implementation in PCM passive cooling devices and thermal storage applications [5]. As such, several researchers have focused their attention to different enhancement techniques proposed to improve the thermal conductivity of the PCMs. These techniques can be, for example, the impregnation of high conductivity porous material with the PCM and the storage of PCM in the inner tube provided with longitudinal fins in a heat exchanger; Jegadheeswaran and Pohekar [6] and Fan and Khodadadi [7] have reviewed most of these efforts. Another potential and interesting application of the PCMs is the energy storage in buildings. In order to reduce energy demand of new buildings and refurbished ones, high performance components are needed to let the building itself manage the transient heat and internal temperature in a passive way, if correctly designed. In building energy systems, the PCM can be inserted into rigid or flexible containers that can be installed in the walls or windows. Polycarbonate panels filled with paraffin, for example, could reduce the indoor air temperature fluctuations and the energy consumption for air conditioning and improve the indoor thermal-hygrometric comfort. In the last years, design criteria have been changed aimed to ensure that occupancy expectations in terms of environmental comfort would be met; passive control strategies have been designed and integrated to enhance performances. It is therefore necessary to properly size the PCM with careful attention to melting temperature and amount of heat provided in an indoor environment. It is of crucial importance the understanding of the transient of the building system through a correct physical modelling. The transient simulation of the building system is very important; in order to achieve reliable results, the thermophysical properties of the building materials must be accurately estimated. This consideration becomes even more important if these materials are able to absorb and reject large heat loads, as in the case of PCMs. In literature, several studies confirm the PCM effectiveness in building’s energy performance. Mandilaras et al. [7] have recently determined, numerically, the
Page 4 of 18
effective heat capacity of a PCM, and Lee et al. [9] have experimentally evaluated the thermal performance of a thin PCM layer integrated in a wall, finding average daily heat transfer reduction of 27.4% for south facing walls and 10.5% for west facing walls. Interesting reviews are those published by Pomianowski et al. [10], with focus on the building application, and that by Soares et al. [11], which concluded that PCMs lead to several advantages when used in passive latent heat thermal energy storage system (LHTES), such as the increment of indoor thermal comfort, the improvement in buildings envelope performance, the increment on systems efficiency, the decrement of the conditioning power needed, the reduction in energy consumption, etc. Cabeza et al. [12] and Fernández et al. [13] are two consecutive reviews about the PCMs characterization. The first one focused on thermophysical properties presenting different instruments for a correct characterization of buildings materials. The latter review analysed different methods to characterize morphological and structural properties of PCM, physic-chemical stability, and mechanical properties. The commonly used PCMs for technical applications are paraffin waxes, salt hydrates, fatty acids, and others [14]. Paraffin waxes are one of the most promising PCMs consisting of mixtures of mostly straight chain n-alkanes CH3–(CH2)n–CH3. Both the melting point and latent heat of fusion increase with chain length. As organic materials, they are safe, non-corrosive, chemically and thermally stable, and they have especially varied phase change temperatures that allow their availability in a large temperature range. This last property allows for a simple and direct application of the paraffin waxes in many different process applications. Unfortunately, as already mentioned before, paraffin waxes also show a very low thermal conductivity, a high volume change during the melting process, and, even if their latent heat cannot be considered very low, it might be increased. Therefore, the addition of nanoparticles to a PCM was proposed by Khodadadi and Hosseinizadeh [15] in order to improve thermal energy storage by increasing heat conductivity. Recent research (e.g. Shin and Banerjee [16], Chieruzzi et al. [17]) verified that nanoparticles could enhance the heat capacity of the molten salt PCM. Zhichao et al. [18] measured 8% total heat storage capacity enhancement dispersing TiO2 nanoparticles at 0.2 vol% in erythritol as PCM. Jiang et al. [19] studied PCM paraffin microcapsules modified with different percentages of nano-Al2O3 obtaining enhanced thermal transfer and phase change properties. Karkri et al. [20] used a PCM
Page 5 of 18
based on high-density polyethylene (HDPE) mixed with micro-encapsulated paraffin wax. The paraffin wax acted as a high-latent-heat material, whereas the HDPE matrix ensured the compact shape. The authors observed a decrement on the PCM thermal conductivity and diffusivity, and an enhancement on the latent, sensible, and total heat of the PCM increasing the paraffin content. He et al. [21] studied thermophysical properties of nanofluids as phase-change material, BaCl2–H2O PCMs, in low temperature cool storage, using TiO2 nanoparticles. Thermal conductivity increased up to 16.7% leading to the use of that PCM suitable for the industries low temperature energy storage, as refrigeration and air conditioning systems, solar energy systems, and heating and cooling of buildings. The present study proposes an experimental investigation of two commercial paraffin waxes with melting temperature of about 20 °C and 25 °C. The phase change process at around the ambient temperature allows the use of their latent heat in common building operations, e.g. to improve indoor air comfort, increase thermal inertia, and decrease energy costs. This work also aims at investigating the feasibility of the addition of Al2O3 and CB nanoparticles to the reference paraffin waxes to obtain nano-PCMs and enhance the thermal properties. Thermal conductivity, specific heat capacity, and latent heat of pure paraffin waxes and nano-PCMs were experimentally investigated, in the temperature range between 10 °C and 60 °C, considering the available paraffin melting temperature.
2. PARAFFIN WAXES AND NANO-PCMs PREPARATION Two commercial paraffin waxes with a melting point about 20 °C and 25 °C, RUBITHERM® RT20 and RUBITHERM® RT25, were purchased from Rubitherm Technologies GmbH (Germany). Al2O3, gamma, hydrophilic, nano-powder was purchased from Nanostructured & Amorphous Materials, Inc. (USA); it has a nominal diameter of 10 nm, 99.99% purity and 160 m 2 /g of Specific Surface Area (SSA). Carbon black (Sid Richardson Carbon Co., USA), N110 type (furnace carbon black, according to ASTM classification), is a monodispersion of chain-like aggregates of spherical primary particles (15-20 nm). The hydrodynamic diameter of the aggregates, measured in NMP by Dynamic Light Scattering, is 170 ±10 nm, the density at 25 °C is 1.8 g/mL and the SSA is 139 m 2 /g (BET method). At the nanoscale level each CB primary particle is organized in stacked graphenic layers arranged in a
Page 6 of 18
concentric fashion. CB was milled in a ball-mill for 20 min before use to assure a fine dispersion of the bulk material. Nanoparticles were added to the liquid paraffin sample, to reach a mass fraction of 1.0% for both RT20 and RT25, using a Mettler PM6100 (FS 6100 g, ± 0.01 g). In the case of Alumina based nano-PCMs, RT20/Al2O3 and RT25/Al2O3, in order to uniformly disperse nanoparticles, the nano-PCMs were mechanically stirred for 20 min at 600 rpm and then they underwent to an ultrasonic procedure using a probe sonicator (Hielscher UP200s). During the sonication process, temperature of the nano-PCMs increased, thus, in order to maintain its temperature under 50 °C, the samples were immersed in a thermostatic bath set at 30 °C, sonicated for at least for 150 min with the temperature of the PCMs monitored every 20 min. In the case of CB based nano-PCMs, RT20/CB and RT25/CB mixtures were kept under stirring in an oil bath for about 30 min allowing a homogenous dispersion of the two components. The samples prepared were then quickly solidified and used for thermal conductivity and latent heat measurements. Table 1 reports the main properties of the selected nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3. EXPERIMENTAL EQUIPMENT
sections.text:
The two base paraffin waxes and the two prepared nano-PCMs were then experimentally characterized to study the effects of the Al2O3 and CB nanoparticles on the solid thermal conductivity, liquid and solid specific heat capacity, and latent heat of fusion.
3.1 Thermal Conductivity Measurement A ThermTest TPS2500S, an instrument based on the Hot Disk technique, was used to measure the thermal conductivity. The instrument works with the transient plane source mode, using as the plane source, a disk sensor (Figure 1) Kapton-insulated to be thermally neutral and it can measure thermal properties of liquids, solids and powders.
It is made from a double spiral of electrically-conducting Nickel metal that works as both transient heater, to increase the temperature of the sample, and precise temperature transducer, to record the time-dependent temperature increase. The
Page 7 of 18
declared instrument uncertainty is 5%; however, it has been calibrated with a standard stainless steel sample showing a deviation always lower than 1.1%. Thermal conductivity was measured placing the sensor between two samples having parallel plane surfaces to ensure a complete contact between sensor and paraffin waxes, as shown in figure 2. The heat transfer is assumed purely conductive and thermal transport properties are determined by the instrument considering the constant electric current supplied by the sensor and the temperature change as a function of time, by monitoring the total resistance of the hot disk sensor.
3.2 Heat capacity and latent heat measurements The solid and liquid specific heat capacity and latent heat were measured by means of a Differential Scanning Calorimeter (DSC), Setaram Instrumentation (Figure 3). The DSC measures specific heat capacity by heating a sample and by measuring the temperature difference between the sample and a reference sample, as a voltage. The equipment is composed by two calorimetric cells in which three measurements are repeated. The first cell always contains an empty pot. The second cell contains an empty pot in the first measurement, a pot with a known reference material, in this case Sapphire, in the second measurement and a pot with the paraffin wax sample in the third measurement. All the samples undergo to the same temperature variation of temperature, at the same velocity. A voltage signal, generated by the equipment, is measured as a function of temperature and velocity of temperature raising/decreasing. Knowing the mass of sapphire and waxes, the specific heat can be calculated. The instrument uncertainty is 2%.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text:
The values of the thermal conductivity of solid PCMs and nano-PCMs were measured at 14 °C, which is around 5 to 10 K below the reference melting temperatures of the two paraffin waxes. The experimental values of the thermal conductivity were 0.254 W/(m K) and 0.261 W/(m K) for the pure paraffin waxes RT20 and RT25, respectively. Table 2 compares the experimental values of thermal conductivity of the tested nano-PCMs obtained during several repeated tests at around 14 °C with those collected for the pure paraffin waxes.
Page 8 of 18
From the experimental results, it clearly appears that the addition of the Alumina nanoparticles leads to a degradation of some 7-8% of the thermal conductivity of the base pure paraffin waxes for both RT20 and RT25. On the contrary, the Carbon Black nanoparticles strongly enhance the thermal conductivity of the pure paraffin waxes, with improvements that reached more than 25%. Latent heat of PCMs and nano-PCMs was measured imposing a programmed variation of temperature, between 10 °C and 67 °C, and with a predefined velocity of 10 K/h. A typical signal output of the Differential Scanning Calorimeter (DSC) is reported in Figure 4. The values of the specific heat capacity measured during the sample heating permit to estimate the specific heat capacity of both solid and liquid and, through a numerical integration of the curve, the solid-liquid phase change latent heat. In particular, Figure 4 shows the difference in the response signals recorded for the two reference paraffin waxes, RT20 and RT25, respectively. The peaks should represent the solid-liquid phase change temperatures, which for the two pure paraffin waxes should nominally be around 293 K and 298 K for RT20 and RT25, respectively. The results show that the peak for the RT25, being around 299 K, falls very closed to its nominal melting temperature, while that of RT20 occurs at a relative higher temperature, around 297 K instead of 293 K. This can be explained considering the two different specific heat capacity curves; in particular, the profile measured for RT25 shows a sharp slope around the melting temperature, while the profile for RT20 exhibits a smooth increase with an isolated peak at around 297 K. In order to control the melting temperature, the paraffin waxes are commonly obtained by mixing many different organic components, the final actual composition of the paraffin wax controls the heat capacity profile and the melting temperature, which in some cases could not be unique.
Similar profiles of the heat capacity were also measured in the case of nano-PCMs; for the sake of brevity, a comparison between the profiles measured for the pure RT25 and the RT25/Al2O3 1%wt is reported in Figure 5. It clearly appears that the addition of the Al2O3 nanoparticles does not shift the melting temperature of both the reference paraffin waxes. Similar results were also found for all the other nano-PCMs. As described before, the peaks of the profiles represent the solid-liquid phase change (i.e. the melting temperature); the values of the latent heat of fusion of the
Page 9 of 18
investigated materials were determined by applying a numerical integration of the recorded curve.
In the case of nano-PCMs, only the paraffin wax undergoes a phase change, while the Al2O3 and CB nanoparticles remain in solid state. Therefore, in the presence of nanoparticles before integrating the peak area, the contribution of 1 wt% of Al2O3 and CB on the measured specific heat capacity (cp,tot) was accounted and subtracted from the overall measured one. The results of the numerical integration are presented in Figures 6 and 7 for the RT20 and RT25 based nano-PCMs, respectively, while Table 3 lists the computed values of latent heat for all the tested PCMs.
The results seem to strongly depend on the base pure paraffin wax; in fact, on average the latent heat of RT20 is increased when 1%wt of both Al2O3 and CB is added. On the contrary, the Alumina nanoparticles does not affect the latent heat of RT25 while when adding CB nanoparticles, the latent heat decreases. In the case of RT20, this result is in agreement with Shaikh et al. [22], which measured a maximum enhancement of 13% in the latent heat of wax with single wall carbon nanotubes at 1 vol.%. They proposed a model based on the Lennard-Jones theory of intermolecular forces, relating it to the change in latent heat of PCM due to the inclusion of nanoparticles. This model provides a good description of the experimental results. Nanoparticles have a large surface area and the intermolecular attraction in the wax/Al2O3 dispersion could explain the enhancement of the latent energy. However, the model fails to explain the behaviour exhibited by the CB based RT25 nano-PCMs; the different affinity between the tested paraffin waxes and the seeded nanoparticles could explain the different results. From this standpoint, it clearly
Page 10 of 18
appears the strong need of additional research efforts to explain how the affinity between the nanoparticles and the base PCMs affects the final thermophysical properties of the nano-PCMs. In order to assess the reliability of the obtained results, the tests were repeated different times on the same sample to check every possible difference due to the phase change, especially on the nanoparticles distribution. In the case of Alumina based nano-PCMs, the repetition of the test after 1 day and after 2 days reveals a decrease in the latent heat. This might be due to a settling phenomenon of nanoparticles after several hours. In fact, after the first measurement, each nano-PCM remains in the liquid state, during which the nanoparticles tend to settle. Therefore, during the second test, a part of the wax did not contain a uniform distribution of the nanoparticles and the most of the sample behaves as the pure base wax. On the contrary, the CB based nano-PCM was found to be extremely stable and repeated calorimetric tests gave almost similar results. The liquid specific heat capacity seems to be only slightly affected by the presence of the nanoparticles; in particular, for example, at 340 K the specific heat capacity of RT20 and RT25 were 2299 and 2291 J/ (kg K), respectively. The nano-PCMs based on those paraffin waxes showed an increase of 2.3% and 1.7% as compared to the reference RT20 and RT25, respectively.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
Two commercial paraffin waxes, having the solid-liquid phase transition at 20 °C and 25 °C, were experimentally studied as thermal energy storage material. An important advantage of these PCMs is that their melting process occurs at around the indoor ambient temperature; therefore, the latent heat of fusion can be used in many different buildings applications. In the present work, aluminium oxide and carbon black nanoparticles were added to the PCMs at a mass fraction of 1%, in order to study the feasibility of this new technique to enhance the thermal properties of the reference paraffin waxes. The thermal conductivity of solid PCMs and nano-PCMs was measured at 14 °C; the results showed that the Al2O3 nanoparticles penalizes the thermal conductivity while the addition of Carbon Black nanoparticles leads to enhancement of 35% and 24%, for RT20/CB and RT25/CB, respectively.
Page 11 of 18
The latent heat measurements were performed using a differential scanning calorimeter. In this case, remarkable enhancement of the latent heat was only observed when the aluminium oxide was added to the RT20 paraffin wax (+10.8%); in general, the addition of CB implies a slight increase (+3.4%) of the latent heat in the case of RT20, while it leads to an overall penalization (-11.6%) for RT25. The Al2O3 based nano-PCMs were found to be unstable and a certain nanoparticle deposition was observed; on the contrary, the CB based nano-PCMs were extremely stable. This work confirms that the use of nanoparticles can be a feasible and viable solution to improve the thermophysical properties of the PCMs, especially the paraffin waxes. Additional experimental and theoretical work is surely needed to understand the underlining heat transfer mechanisms on the basis of the performance of the paraffin waxes in order to develop rigorous procedure for the nano-PCMs development and characterization, as well as their stabilization.

metadata.abstractText: It is well known that the heat transfer associated with a phase change process is much higher than sensible enthalpy change even in forced convection. In particular, the vaporization process has been widely studied because it exploits the highest heat transfer coefficient; this heat transfer mechanism is used in both passive (i.e. heat pipes) and active (i.e. refrigerating machines) cooling devices. However, the solidliquid phase change process is another interesting possibility to reject even high heat loads, especially when they are intermittent. The term Phase Change Materials (PCMs) commonly refers to those materials, which use the solid-liquid phase change process to adsorb and then release heat loads [1]. The present work aims at investigating the feasibility of a new challenging use of Aluminium Oxide (Al2O3) and Carbon Black (CB) nanoparticles to enhance the thermal properties: thermal conductivity, specific heat, and latent heat of pure paraffin waxes to obtain a new class of PCMs, the so-called nano-PCMs. The nano-PCMs were obtained by seeding 1%wt of nanoparticles in paraffin waxes with melting temperatures of 20 °C and 25 °C. The thermophysical properties were then measured to understand the effects of the nanoparticles on the thermal properties of both the solid and liquid PCM. These new nano-PCMs can represent a feasible and interesting way to mitigate or eliminate the intrinsic limitations in the use of paraffin waxes as PCMs for both energy storage and passive cooling applications.
